book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Warning against being deceived by the world. Allah the Almighty said: (O you who have believed, let not your wealth and your children divert you from remembrance of Allah. And whoever does that - then those are the losers. And spend [in the way of Allah] from what We have provided you before death approaches one of you and he says, 'My Lord, if only You would delay me for a brief term so I would give charity and be among the righteous.' But never will Allah delay a soul when its time has come. And Allah is Acquainted with what you do.) [Al-Munafiqun: 9-11]. In the book of Tirmidhi, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Frequently remember the destroyer of pleasures: death.' In the two Sahihs, on the authority of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'It is not right for a Muslim man who has something to bequeath to stay for two nights without his will being written and kept with him.' In the narration of Muslim: 'To stay for three nights.' Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: 'Not a night has passed me since I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say that, except that my will is with me.' In Sahih Al-Bukhari, on the authority of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, he said: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, took hold of my shoulder and said: Be in the world as if you were a stranger or a wayfarer, and count yourself among the inhabitants of the graves.' Meaning, do not lean towards it, do not take it as a homeland, do not tell yourself you will remain long in it, do not concern yourself with it, and do not cling to it with what a stranger does not cling to in a land other than his own. Do not occupy yourself in it with what occupies a stranger who wants to go to his family. Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, used to say: 'If you reach the evening, do not wait for the morning, and if you reach the morning, do not wait for the evening. Take from your health for your sickness, and from your life for your death.' The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Two things the son of Adam dislikes: He dislikes death, yet death is better'

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: for the believer than fitnah (trial/temptation); and he dislikes the scarcity of wealth, yet scarce wealth means less accountability.' Hatim al-Asam said: 'Everything has an adornment, and the adornment of worship is fear, and the sign of fear is shortening hope.' It was said to Al-Hasan: 'Will you not wash your shirt?' He said: 'The matter is more urgent than that.' Know that it is Sunnah for every responsible person (Mukallaf) to frequently remember death, and one should prepare for it by repenting to Allah Almighty and returning usurped rights. This is even more emphasized for the sick because it softens his heart and causes him to fear, so he returns from injustices and turns towards acts of obedience. Know that the children of Adam are of two groups: A group that looked at the visible illusion of the world and held onto the hope of a long life and did not reflect on the final breath. And a group of wise people who placed the final breath before their eyes to look at what their destination will be, how they will leave the world and depart from it, whether their faith will be intact, what of the world will descend with them into their graves, and what they will leave for their enemies while the burden and punishment of it remain upon them. This reflection is obligatory upon all creation, and it is even more obligatory upon kings and people of the world because they have often disturbed the hearts of creation and instilled terror in their hearts. For the Truth (Allah), may His mention be exalted, has an angel known as the Angel of Death; there is no escape for anyone from his pursuit and his grasp. All agents of kings accept a bribe of gold and food, but this agent takes nothing but the soul as a bribe. With all other agents of sultans, intercession is useful, but with this agent, the intercession of an intercessor is of no use. All agents grant respite to those they are assigned to for a day or an hour, but this agent does not neglect a single breath. It is narrated that there was a king of great wealth who had gathered a vast fortune and amassed every type of worldly good created by Allah Almighty to indulge himself and free himself to consume what he had gathered. He gathered abundant blessings, built a lofty, high, and imposing palace suitable for kings, princes, elders, and the great, installed two sturdy gates on it, and stationed boys, executioners, and guards upon it

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: and soldiers and doorkeepers as he desired. He ordered some people to prepare the finest food for him and gathered his family, entourage, companions, and servants to eat with him and receive his gifts. He sat on the throne of his kingdom, leaned on his cushion, and said: 'O soul, you have gathered the blessings of the world in their entirety, so now free yourself for this and eat these blessings, enjoying a long life and abundant fortune.' He had not finished speaking to himself when a man came from outside the palace, wearing worn-out clothes, with a satchel hanging from his neck, in the appearance of a beggar asking for food. He came and knocked the door ring with a mighty, terrifying knock such that the palace shook and the throne trembled. The servants were frightened and leaped to the door, shouting at the knocker, saying: 'O guest, what is this rudeness and bad manners? Wait until we eat and we will give you what is left over.' He said to them: 'Tell your master to come out to me, for I have important business with him and a serious matter.' They said to him: 'Step aside, O guest! Who are you that we should order our master to come out to you?' He said: 'You inform him of what I mentioned to you.' When they informed him, he said: 'Why did you not rebuke him, act harshly towards him, and scold him?' Then he knocked the door ring even harder than the first knock. They rose from their places with sticks and weapons, intending to fight him. He shouted at them with a shout and said: 'Stay in your places, for I am the Angel of Death.' Their minds went blank, their muscles trembled, and their limbs ceased to move. The King said: 'Tell him to take a substitute for me and a replacement instead of me.' He said: 'I will take nothing but your soul, and I did not come except for your sake, to separate between you and the blessings you gathered and the wealth you contained and stored.' He sighed deeply and said: 'May Allah curse this wealth which deceived me, distanced me, and prevented me from worshipping my Lord. I used to think it would benefit me, but today it has become my regret and my trial; I leave empty-handed from it, and it remains for my enemies.' Allah Almighty caused the wealth to speak until it said: 'For what reason do you curse me? Curse yourself! For Allah Almighty created me and you from dust, and placed me in your hand so that you may take provisions from me for your afterlife, give charity from me to the poor, give Zakat from me to the weak, and build with me hospices, mosques, bridges, and archways, to be a help to you on the Last Day. You gathered me and stored me, and spent me on your desires. You did not thank my right, but rather you were ungrateful for me. So now you leave me to your enemies while you remain with your regret and your trial. So what is my sin that you curse me and revile me?' Then the Angel of Death seized his soul before he could eat the food, and he fell upon his throne, a victim of death:

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Prepare for the graves—woe to you—and the tomb... A provision of piety for the longest imprisonment. / For you do not know, if you reach the morning... In the best state you hope for, perhaps you will not reach the evening. / I will tire my soul so that I may find rest... For the humiliation of the soul is honor for the soul. / And renounce the world, for its resident... Restrains his anger regarding it; how similar today is to yesterday.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Preparation for the Descent of Death. Allah Almighty said: (Until, when death comes to one of them, he says, 'My Lord, send me back. That I might do righteousness in that which I left behind.' No! It is only a word he is saying; and behind them is a barrier until the Day they are resurrected. So when the Horn is blown, no relationship will there be among them that Day, nor will they ask about one another.) to the end of the Surah. And on the authority of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, planted a stick in front of him, and another by his side, and another further away. He said: 'Do you know what this is?' They said: 'Allah and His Messenger know best.' He said: 'This is the human, and this is his destined time (Ajal), and this is his hope (Amal). He chases hope, but the destined time overtakes him before the hope.' It is narrated on the authority of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said to a man while admonishing him: 'Take advantage of five before five: Your youth before your old age, your health before your sickness, your wealth before your poverty, your free time before your busyness, and your life before your death.' Imam Abu Hamid Al-Ghazali wrote to Sheikh Abu Al-Fath bin Salamah: 'It has reached my hearing that you seek from me brief words by way of advice and preaching. I do not see myself worthy of that, for preaching is a Zakat (alms) whose threshold (Nisab) is self-admonition. So he who has no threshold, how can he pay Zakat? And he who lacks light, how can others be illuminated by him? And when will the shadow be straight if the stick is crooked?' Allah Almighty advised Jesus, son of Mary, peace be upon them: 'O Son of Mary, admonish yourself; if you accept the admonition, then admonish the people, otherwise be shy of Me.' Our Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'I have left among you a speaker and a silent one.' The speaker is the Quran and the silent one is Death. In them is sufficiency for every person who takes heed. And he who does not take heed from them, how can he admonish others? Indeed, I have admonished myself with them, and it accepted and believed in word and deed, but refused and rebelled in realization and action. So I said to my soul: 'Are you not a believer?'

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: that the Quran is the Speaking Preacher and that it is the speech of Allah revealed, which falsehood cannot approach from before it or from behind it? She (my soul) said: 'Yes.' So I said to her: Allah Almighty has said: (Whoever desires the life of this world and its adornments - We fully repay them for their deeds therein, and they therein will not be deprived. Those are the ones for whom there is not in the Hereafter but the Fire. And lost is what they did therein, and worthless is what they used to do.) Allah has promised the Fire for desiring the world, and everything that does not accompany one after death is from the world. So have you elevated yourself above the love of the world and desiring it? If a Christian doctor promised you death or sickness for consuming the most delicious desires, you would avoid them, protect yourself, and disdain them. Is the Christian more truthful to you than Allah Almighty? If that is so, how great is your disbelief! Or is the sickness more severe to you than the Fire? If that is so, how great is your ignorance! She conceded, but did not benefit; rather, she persisted in inclining towards the immediate life and continued. Then I turned to her and admonished her with the [other] preacher, so I said to her: The Speaker has informed about the Silent One. Allah Almighty said: (Say, 'Indeed, the death from which you flee - indeed, it will meet you. Then you will be returned to the Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, and He will inform you about what you used to do.') And I said to her: Suppose you incline to the immediate life, do you not believe that death will inevitably come to you, cutting off what you are holding onto and stripping from you everything you desire? And that everything which is coming is near, and the distant is that which is not coming? Allah Almighty has said: (Have you considered: if We gave them enjoyment for years, Then there came to them that which they were promised, Of no avail to them would be whatever they were given of enjoyment.) So it is as if you are removed by this admonition from everything you are in. She said: 'You have spoken the truth.' But it was from her a saying behind which nothing resulted. She never strove in gathering provisions for the Hereafter like her striving in managing the immediate life, nor did she strive for the pleasure of Allah Almighty like her striving to seek her own pleasure and seek

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: the pleasure of creation. She was not shy before Allah Almighty as she is shy before a single person from creation. She did not roll up her sleeves to prepare for the Hereafter like her preparation in the summer for the sake of winter, and in the winter for the sake of summer. For she does not feel secure in the beginning of winter unless she has freed herself to gather all she needs for it, even though death might snatch her away and winter might not reach her, while the Hereafter is to her a certainty, so it is inconceivable that it be snatched away from her. So I said to her: 'Do you not prepare for summer according to its length, and make tools for summer according to your patience with the heat?' She said: 'Yes.' I said: 'Then disobey Allah according to your patience with the Fire, and prepare for the Hereafter according to your remaining in it.' She said: 'This is the duty which no one is permitted to abandon except a fool.' Then she continued on her nature, and I found myself as some wise men said: 'Among people is he whom half of him is rebuked, yet his other half is not rebuked,' and I do not see myself but as one of them. When I saw her persisting in transgression, not benefiting from the admonitions of death and the Quran, I saw the most important matter was to investigate the cause of her persistence despite her confession and belief, for that is among the great wonders. My investigation into it was prolonged until I stood upon its cause. Here I am advising myself and you to beware of it. It is the great disease and the cause calling to delusion and negligence: it is the belief in the delay of death and considering its sudden attack unlikely in the near future. For if a truthful person informed one during the daylight that he would die in his night, or die within a week or a month, he would straighten up on the Straight Path and leave everything he is in—which he thinks he is doing for Allah Almighty while he is deceived in it—let alone what is not for Allah Almighty. It was revealed to me with certainty that whoever wakes up hoping to reach the evening, or reaches the evening hoping to wake up, is not free from lethargy and procrastination and is only capable of a weak pace. So I advise you and myself with what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, advised when he said: 'Pray the prayer of one bidding farewell.' Indeed, he was given the concise speech and the decisive word. One does not benefit from preaching except through this. Whoever believes predominantly in every prayer that it is his last prayer, his fear of Allah Almighty and his awe of Him are present with him. And whoever does not have this thought cross his mind, his life is shortened [in blessing], his death approaches, his heart neglects his prayer, and his soul becomes bored. He remains in perpetual negligence, constant lethargy, and successive procrastination until death overtakes him and destroys him with the regret of missed opportunity. I propose to him that he asks Allah Almighty to grant me this rank, for I am a seeker of it but fall short of it. And I advise him not to be satisfied with himself except

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: with it, and to beware of the places of delusion in it, and to guard against the deception of the soul, for its deception is not detected except by the intelligent, and how few they are. The instructions, even if many, and the mentioned matters, even if great, the instruction of Allah is the most perfect, most beneficial, and most comprehensive. Allah Almighty has said in the decisive Quran: (And We have instructed those who were given the Scripture before you and yourselves to fear Allah.) How happy is he who accepts the instruction of Allah Almighty, acts upon it, and stores it for himself to find it on the day of his return and destination. Yazid al-Raqashi said: 'There was a tyrant among the tyrants of the Children of Israel. One day he was sitting on the throne of his kingdom when he saw a man who had entered from the door of the house, possessing a terrifying appearance and a frightening form. His fear intensified at his intrusion, his appearance, and his arrival. He leaped in his face and said to him: 'Who are you, O man, and who gave you permission to enter my house?' He said: ' The Owner of the house gave me permission. I am the one whom no doorkeeper can block, I do not need permission to enter upon kings, I do not fear the authority of a Sultan, no tyrant frightens me, and no one can flee from my grasp.' When he heard these words, he fell on his face and trembling seized his body. He said: 'You are the Angel of Death.' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'I adjure you by Allah to grant me respite for one day so that I may repent from my sin, ask forgiveness from my Lord, and return the wealth I deposited in my treasuries to its owners, so I do not bear the hardship of its punishment.' He said: 'How can I grant you respite when the days of your life are counted and its times are recorded and written?' He said: 'Grant me an hour.' He said: 'Indeed, the hours are in the account; they have passed while you were heedless, and ended while you were oblivious. You have exhausted your breaths and not a single breath remains for you.' He said: 'Who will be with me when you transfer me to my grave?' He said: 'Nothing will be with you except your deeds.' He said: 'I have no deeds?' He said: 'Undoubtedly, your resting place will be in the Fire and your destination to the anger of the Compeller.' And he seized his soul, so he fell from his throne. The clamor of the people of his kingdom rose and elevated. If they knew what he was going to from the wrath of his Lord, their weeping for him would be greater and their wailing more abundant.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Condemnation of Long Hope (Al-Amal). Allah Almighty said: (Has the time not come for those who have believed that their hearts should become humbly submissive at the remembrance of Allah and what has come down of the truth? And let them not be like those who were given the Scripture before, and a long period passed over them, so their hearts hardened; and many of them are defiantly disobedient.) On the authority of Ubayy bin Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: 'When a third of the night had passed, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would stand up and say: O people, remember Allah! The Quaking One (Al-Rajifah) has come, followed by the Subsequent One (Al-Radifah). Death has come with what is in it.' On the authority of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to spill water (urinate) and then perform Tayammum with dust. I would say: 'O Messenger of Allah, the water is near to you.' He would say: 'How do I know? Perhaps I will not reach it.' On the authority of Anas, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The son of Adam grows old, but two things remain young in him: Greed for wealth and greed for life.' And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The likeness of the son of Adam: by his side are ninety-nine deaths; if the deaths miss him, he falls into old age.' It is narrated that Al-Hasan was told that so-and-so died suddenly. He said: 'What surprises you about that? If he did not die suddenly, he would have fallen ill suddenly and then died.' Al-Ghazali, may Allah have mercy on him, said: 'You must avoid long hope, for if it is prolonged, it stirs up four things: First, abandoning obedience and laziness in it; he says, 'I will do it later,' and the days are ahead. Second, abandoning repentance and postponing it; he says, 'I will repent later,' and there is ample time in the days, and I am young with few years, and repentance is in my hands whenever I desire it. Perhaps death assassinates him while persisting [in sin], and the destined time snatches away the rectifying of deeds. Third, greed for gathering wealth and occupying oneself with the world over the Hereafter; he says, 'I fear poverty in old age, and perhaps I will become too weak to earn, so I must have something extra to store for sickness, old age, or poverty.' This and similar thoughts stir up desire for the world, greed for it, and concern for provision. You say, 'What will I eat and what will I wear this winter and this summer?' and 'I have nothing.' Perhaps life will be long so I will need it, and need combined with grey hair is severe, and I must have sustenance and independence from people. This

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: and its likes stir one to seek the world, desire it, gather for it, and withhold what you have of it. Fourth, hardness of the heart and forgetfulness of the Hereafter, because if you hope for a long life, you do not remember death and the grave.' And from Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him: 'What I fear most for you are two things: long hope and following desires. Indeed, long hope makes one forget the Hereafter, and following desires blocks you from the truth. Thus, your thought becomes about the talk of the world and the means of living in the company of creation towards it, so the heart hardens. Due to long hope, obedience decreases, repentance is delayed, disobedience increases, greed intensifies, the heart hardens, and negligence becomes great. So it goes, and we seek refuge in Allah. If Allah does not have mercy, what state is worse than this, and what affliction is greater than this? Indeed, the softness of the heart and its purity come from remembering death, its suddenness, the grave, reward and punishment, and the states of the Hereafter.' It is narrated that Dhul-Qarnayn passed by a people who owned nothing of the means of the world. They had dug the graves of their dead at the doors of their houses and were constantly tending to those graves, cleaning them, visiting them, and worshipping Allah Almighty among them. They had no food except grass and the plants of the earth. So Dhul-Qarnayn sent a man to them summoning their king, but he did not answer him and said: 'I have no need of him.' So Dhul-Qarnayn came to him and said: 'How is your condition? For I see no gold or silver, and I see nothing of the blessings of the world with you.' He said: 'Yes, because no one is ever satisfied with the world.' He said: 'Why did you dig the graves at your doors?' He said: 'So that they may be before our eyes; looking at them renews the remembrance of death and cools the love of the world in our hearts, so we are not distracted by it from worshipping our Lord.' He said: 'How do you eat grass?' He said: 'Because we hate to make our stomachs graveyards for animals, and because the pleasure of food does not go beyond the throat.' Then he extended his hand and brought out a human skull, placed it in front of him, and said: 'O Dhul-Qarnayn, do you know who this was?' He said: 'No.' He said: 'The owner of this skull was a king among the kings of the world. He used to oppress his subjects, tyrannize the weak, and spend his time gathering the world. So Allah seized his soul and made the Fire his abode, and this is his head.' Then he extended his hand and placed another skull in front of him and said to him: 'Do you know this one?' He said: 'No.' He said: 'This was a just king, compassionate to his subjects, loving the people of his kingdom. So Allah seized his soul, lodged him in His Paradise, and raised his rank.' Then he placed his hand on the head of Dhul-Qarnayn and said:

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: 'See which of these two heads this head will be?' Dhul-Qarnayn wept intensely and hugged him to his chest and said to him: 'If you desire my companionship, I will hand over my ministry to you and share my kingdom with you.' He said: 'Far from it! I have no desire for that.' He said: 'Why?' He said: 'Because all creation are your enemies because of wealth and kingdom, and all of them are my friends because of contentment and poverty.' How excellent is the poet who said: Your evidence is that poverty is better than wealth... And that little wealth is better than abundance. / You meet a servant who disobeyed Allah through wealth... But you never met a servant who disobeyed Allah through poverty.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Shortening Hope. Know that shortening hope while loving the world is impossible, and waiting for death while being engrossed in it is not feasible. If [the heart] is filled with something, there is no place for something else in it. Also because the world and the Hereafter are like two co-wives; if you please one, you anger the other. And like the East and the West; however much you approach one, you distance yourself from the other. Allah Almighty said: (Whoever should desire the immediate - We hasten for him from it what We will to whom We intend. Then We have made for him Hell, which he will [enter to] burn, censured and banished.) And Allah Almighty said: (So let not the worldly life deceive you and let not the Deceiver deceive you about Allah.) The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed, the world is sweet and green, and indeed Allah is making you successors in it, so He looks at how you act. So fear the world and fear women, for the first trial of the Children of Israel was women.' And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Two hungry wolves sent into a sheep pen are not more corrupting to it than a man's greed for wealth and honor is to his religion.' On the authority of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed, what I fear most for you after me is what will be opened for you of the bloom of the world and its adornment.' A man said: 'O Messenger of Allah, does good bring evil?' The Prophet remained silent until we thought that revelation was descending upon him. Then he wiped the sweat from his brow and said: 'Where is the questioner?' As if he praised him. And he said: 'Indeed, good does not bring evil. But indeed, of what the spring grows, some kills or sickens (causes indigestion). Except for the animal that eats vegetation; it eats until its flanks are stretched, then it faces the sun, defecates and urinates, then returns and eats. Indeed, this wealth is green and sweet. So whoever takes it by its right and places it in its right, then what an excellent aid it is. And whoever takes it without its right is like the one who eats and is not satisfied, and it will be a witness against him on the Day of Resurrection.' He means the example of abundant wealth is like the example of what

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: grows in the spring season. Some plants are sweet in the mouth of the animal, and it is greedy to eat them, but perhaps it eats too much, so it gets a disease from overeating and dies from that disease or comes close to dying. But if the animal eats only what its stomach can bear, eats and then stops eating until what it ate is digested and until it urinates and defecates, getting relief from the exit of dung and urine, then the eating does not harm it. Likewise, he who acquires much wealth; greed for wealth, excessive eating, drinking, and beautification harden his heart, make his soul arrogant, and he sees himself as better than others. He despises people and harms them, and does not discharge the rights of the wealth such as Zakat, performing expiations and vows, feeding beggars and guests, and the rights of the neighbor. Whoever fits this description, there is no doubt that wealth is evil for him, distances him from Paradise, and brings him closer to the Fire. But whoever fulfills the rights of wealth, does not despise people, does not boast over them, and does not occupy himself with gathering wealth such that he misses obedience, and does good to people, then his wealth is good for him, as he, peace be upon him, said: 'Excellent is the righteous wealth for the righteous man.' If you know this, you know that good and evil do not come to a man from the wealth itself, but rather the soul of the man is what directs the wealth into what is good for him or evil for him. This was said by Al-Mazhari. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Every nation has a trial, and the trial of my nation is wealth.' And he, peace be upon him, said: 'Allah Almighty says: O Son of Adam, free yourself for My worship, I will fill your chest with richness and close your poverty. And if you do not do so, I will fill your hands with busyness and will not close your poverty.' It is narrated that Rabi'a Al-Adawiyya, may Allah be pleased with her, used to say: 'Every day has a night, and this is my night in which I might die,' so she would not sleep until morning. And she would say to the day likewise, so she would not sleep until evening. Abu Bakr bin Ayyash said: 'I have completed the Quran in this corner eighteen thousand times.' Ibn Al-Mu'tamir fasted for forty years and stood its nights in prayer. Sulaiman Al-Taimi did not rest his side for twenty years. Abdul Qadir Al-Jilani, may Allah have mercy on him, prayed the Fajr prayer with the ablution of Isha for forty years. Al-Ghazali committed himself to seclusion and the duties of his time in acts of good, such that not a moment passed except in obedience—recitation, teaching, looking into Hadith, especially Al-Bukhari, and perpetual fasting and night prayer and sitting with the people of hearts, until

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: he moved to the mercy of Allah Almighty. Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, did not rest his side on the ground for about two years, and he would not waste any time in night or day except in the duty of engaging with knowledge, even while walking in the road coming and going, he would engage in repetition and study. Their stories in rushing towards good deeds are many; what we mentioned suffices for those whom Allah guides. All of that is the result of shortening hope. Know that what helps you to remember death is to remember those who passed away from your relatives, brothers, companions, and peers who passed before you. They used to be as greedy as you, strive as you strive, and work in the world as you work. Then death broke their necks, tore out their roots, snapped their backbones, and bereaved their loved ones of them. They were singled out in their desolate graves and became terrifying corpses. The eyes flowed away, the colors changed, the eloquence vanished, and the heads altered and tilted. With a trial that seats them and questions them about what they used to believe. Then their seat in Paradise or Hell is revealed to them until the Day they are resurrected. They see a changed earth, a split sky, a wound-up sun, falling stars, descending angels, terrifying horrors, spread-out pages, a roaring fire, and a decorated Paradise. So count yourself among them. Do not neglect the provision for your return, and do not leave yourself aimless like cattle grazing without knowing. (Leave them to eat and enjoy, and let them be diverted by [false] hope, for they are going to know.) (When the shackles are around their necks and the chains; they will be dragged. In boiling water; then in the Fire they will be filled [with flame].) O builder of the great palace... Between the villages and the castles. / And strip the army that... Filled the plain and the chests. / And conqueror of the land that... Exhausted (others) over the passage of time. / Have you not finished? Do not leave... Building your grave among the graves.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Look at him, you will see how... To you, obstructing, he points. / And remember your sleep in its midst... Under the stones and rocks. / Those armies have been scattered... And those matters have changed. / You have exchanged the fine silk... For the roughness of the large stone. / And left held hostage by it... No wealth, woe to you, nor kin. / Confused, declaring sorrow... Regretful, calling out for destruction. / And you were called by your name after... You used to be called the Prince.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Agonies of Death (Sakrat al-Mawt). Allah Almighty said: (Every soul will taste death, and you will only be given your [full] compensation on the Day of Resurrection. So he who is drawn away from the Fire and admitted to Paradise has attained [his desire]. And what is the life of this world except the enjoyment of delusion.) And He Almighty said: (And the intoxication of death will bring the truth; that is what you were trying to avoid.) Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih that Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had a small vessel of water before him. He started dipping his hands in the water and wiping his face with them, saying: There is no god but Allah, indeed death has agonies. Then he raised his hands and started saying: To the Highest Companion, until he passed away.' And in his Sahih: 'When the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, became heavy (with illness), distress began to overwhelm him. Fatima, may Allah be pleased with her, started saying: O the distress of my father! He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: There is no distress upon your father after today.' It is narrated that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, entered upon a sick man and said: 'I know what he is encountering. There is not a vein except that it feels pain from death to its utmost intensity.' It is narrated from Makhul from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: 'If a hair from the hairs of the deceased were placed upon the inhabitants of the heavens and the earth, they would die by the permission of Allah Almighty.' Omar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'O Ka'b, tell us about death.' He said: 'Yes, O Commander of the Faithful. It is like a branch with many thorns introduced into the interior of a man, so every thorn hooks onto a vein. Then a man pulls it with a violent pull, taking what he takes and leaving what he leaves.' Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, used to encourage fighting in the way of Allah and say: 'If you are not killed, you will die. By the One in whose hand is the soul of Muhammad, a thousand strikes with the sword are easier than death on a bed.' Shaddad bin Aws said: 'Death is the most terrible horror in this world and the Hereafter for the believer. It is more severe than being sawed with saws, cut with scissors, and boiled in pots. If the dead were resurrected and informed the people of the world about the pain of death, they would not benefit from life nor find pleasure in sleep.' It is narrated that Abraham, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he died, Allah Almighty said to him: 'How did you find death?' He said: 'Like a skewer placed in wet wool then pulled.' He said:

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: 'Indeed, We made it easy for you.' And from Moses, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, that when his soul went to Allah Almighty, He said to him: 'O Moses, how did you find death?' He said: 'I found myself like a live sheep being skinned by the hand of the butcher.' Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah mentioned from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: 'Narrate about the Children of Israel and there is no harm, for among them were wonders.' Then he began to narrate, saying: 'A group went out and came to a cemetery of theirs. They said: If we prayed two rak'ahs and supplicated to Allah to bring out for us some of the dead to inform us about death. He said: So they did. While they were like that, a man poked his head out of a grave, with the trace of prostration between his eyes. He said: O you people, what did you want with me? By Allah, I died one hundred years ago, yet the heat of death has not subsided from me until now. So pray to Allah to return me as I was.' Amru bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with him, used to say: 'I wish I could see a wise, intelligent man whom death has descended upon, so he could inform me about death.' When death descended upon him, it was said to him: 'O Abu Abdullah, you used to say in the days of your life, I wish I could see a wise, intelligent man whom death has descended upon to inform me about death. You are that wise, intelligent man, and death has descended upon you, so inform us about it.' He said: 'I find it as if the heavens have collapsed upon the earth and I am between them, and as if my soul is exiting through the eye of a needle.' It is narrated that Ibrahim the Friend (Khalil) said to the Angel of Death: 'Can you show me the form in which you take the soul of the wicked?' He said: 'Can you bear that?' He said: 'Yes.' So he turned away, then looked, and behold, he was a man in black clothes, with dark hair, foul-smelling, with flames of fire and smoke coming out of his mouth and nostrils. Ibrahim fainted, then woke up, and the Angel of Death had returned to his first form. He said: 'O Angel of Death, if the wicked person met nothing but the image of your face, that would be sufficient for him.' It is narrated from Aslam, the freed slave of Omar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: 'If there remains upon

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: the believer anything of his sins that his deeds did not cover, death is made severe upon him so that he may reach his rank in Paradise through the agonies and severity of death. And indeed, if the disbeliever had good deeds known in the world, death is made easy for him so that he may complete the reward of his good deeds in the world, then he proceeds to the Fire.' Al-Bukhari narrated that Omar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'If I had the earth's fill of gold, I would ransom myself with it from before I see him (the Angel of Death or the punishment).' It was said: The son of Adam has not encountered anything more severe than death, and what is after it is more severe than it. In Al-Waseet by Al-Wahidi, with his chain of transmission from Ibn Abbas, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Illnesses and pains are all messengers of death and envoys of death. So when the appointed time comes, the Angel of Death comes himself and says: O servant, how many reports after reports, and how many messengers after messengers, and how many envoys after envoys? I am the report after which there is no report, and I am the messenger after whom there is no messenger. Answer your Lord, willingly or unwillingly. When he seizes his soul and they scream over him, he says: Over whom do you scream and over whom do you weep? By Allah, I did not wrong his lifespan, nor did I eat his provision. Rather, his Lord called him. So let the weeper weep for himself, for I have repeated returns among you, and returns until I do not leave a single one of you.' From Anas bin Malik, he said: 'Gabriel met the Angel of Death at a river in Persia. He said: O Angel of Death, how can you seize souls during a plague? Here are ten thousand and here are such and such. The Angel of Death said: The earth is folded for me until they are as if between my thighs, so I pick them up with my hand.' Know that if we were waiting for the blow of a policeman, our life would be distressed. Yet in every breath, the arrival of death with its hardships is possible, and it is more bitter than being struck by swords and sawed by saws. He wishes he could scream and groan. His soul is pulled from every muscle and vein; his feet grow cold, then his thighs, and so on until it reaches the throat. At that point, his sight of his world is cut off and the door of his repentance is closed to him. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed Allah Almighty accepts the repentance of His servant as long as he does not gargle (the death rattle).' O group of loved ones, I must leave you... O abode of the world, I am departing from you. / O shortness of days, what do I have to do with hopes... O agonies of death, what do I have to do with laughter. / Why do I not weep for myself with a tear... If I do not weep for myself, who will weep? / Lo, which living person is not certain of death... And which certainty is more like doubt today?

O agonies of death, what do I have to do with laughter. / Why do I not weep for myself with a tear... If I do not weep for myself, who will weep? / Lo, which living person is not certain of death... book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Punishment of the Grave for Disbelievers and Some Disobedient Believers. Allah, Glorious and Exalted, said: (The Fire, they are exposed to it morning and evening. And the Day the Hour appears [it will be said], 'Make the people of Pharaoh enter the severest punishment.') In the book of Tirmidhi, Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, when he stood over a grave, would weep until he wet his beard. It was said to him: 'You remember Paradise and Hell and do not weep, but you weep from this?' He said: 'I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: The grave is the first stage of the stages of the Hereafter; if its companion is saved from it, then what comes after it is easier than it. And if he is not saved from it, then what comes after it is more severe than it.' And I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: 'I have never seen a sight except that the grave is more horrible than it.' In the books of Abu Dawood and Al-Nasa'i, on the authority of Al-Bara' bin Azib, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: 'Two angels come to him and make him sit up. They say to him: Who is your Lord? He says: My Lord is Allah. They say to him: What is your religion? He says: My religion is Islam. They say to him: What is this man who was sent among you? He says: He is the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. They say: And how do you know? He says: I read the Book of Allah and believed in it and verified it. That is His saying: (Allah keeps firm those who believe, with the firm word, in worldly life and in the Hereafter.) He said: Then a caller calls from the sky: My servant has spoken the truth, so furnish him from Paradise, clothe him from Paradise, and open for him a door to Paradise. So its breeze and fragrance come to him, and it is expanded for him therein as far as his eye can see. As for the disbeliever,' he mentioned his death and said: 'His soul is returned to his body, and two angels come to him and make him sit up. They say: Who is your Lord? He says: Hah, hah, I do not know. They say: What is your religion? He says: Hah, hah, I do not know. They say: What is this man who was sent among you? He says: Hah, hah, I do not know. Then a caller calls from the sky: He has lied, so furnish him from the Fire, clothe him from the Fire, and open for him a door to the Fire. He said: So its heat and scorching wind come to him. He said: And his grave narrows upon him until his ribs interlock.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Then a blind, deaf (being) is appointed over him with an iron sledgehammer; if he were to strike a mountain with it, it would become dust. He strikes him with it a blow that everything between the East and the West hears, except the two weighty ones (Jinn and Humans), and he becomes dust, then the soul is returned to him. In the book of Tirmidhi, from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered for prayer and saw people looking as if they were grinning (or talking excessively). He said: 'Behold, if you frequently remembered the destroyer of pleasures, it would distract you from what I see. So frequently remember the destroyer of pleasures: death. For indeed, the grave does not pass a day without saying: I am the house of alienation, I am the house of solitude, I am the house of dust, and I am the house of worms. When the believing servant is buried, the grave says to him: Welcome and greetings. Indeed, you were among the most beloved of those who walked upon my back to me. So since I have been given charge of you and you have come to me, you will see my treatment of you. He said: So it expands for him as far as his eye can see, and a door from Paradise is opened for him. And when the wicked or disbelieving servant is buried, the grave says to him: No welcome and no greetings. Indeed, you were among the most hated of those who walked upon my back to me. So since I have been given charge of you today and you have come to me, you will see my treatment of you. He said: So it closes in on him until it meets and his ribs interlock.' He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, gestured with his fingers, interlacing them. He said: 'And seventy dragons are appointed over him; if one of them were to breathe on the earth, it would not grow anything as long as the world remained. They bite him and scratch him until he is brought to the Reckoning.' He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The grave is either a garden from the gardens of Paradise or a pit from the pits of Hell.' It is narrated that a man entered upon Omar bin Abdul Aziz, may Allah be pleased with him, and saw that his color had changed from excessive worship. He began to marvel at the change in his color and the transformation of his appearance. Omar said to him: 'O son of my brother, what marvels you about me? How (would you be) if you saw me three days after entering my grave, when the pupils have popped out and flowed onto the cheeks, the lips have shrunk away from the teeth, pus and worms have come out of the nostrils and mouth, the belly has swollen and risen above the chest, and the rear has exited from the loins? You would see then something more amazing than what you see now.' Bakr the Worshipper used to say to his mother: 'O mother, I wish you had been barren of me. Indeed, your son has a long imprisonment in the grave, and after that, a departure.'

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Hatim al-Asam said: 'Whoever passes by the courtyard of the graves and does not think about himself and does not pray for them has betrayed himself and betrayed them.' Al-Qushayri said: I heard Abu Ali Al-Daqqaq say: 'I entered upon Imam Abu Bakr bin Furak to visit him (when sick). When he saw me, his eyes teared up. So I said to him: Indeed, Allah will heal you and cure you. He said to me: Do you think I fear death? I only fear what is beyond death.' And I heard some of the poor (Sufis) say that the cause of Dawood bin Nasr Al-Ta'i's asceticism was that he heard a mourning woman wailing: 'With which of your cheeks will you show the decay? And which of your eyes (will go first) when they flow?' How strange! If a doctor described your disease and your medicine to you, you would listen to him and obey him. Yet this is the medicine for your great, buried disease which causes its owner to burn in the Fire of Hell, but you do not listen to it with true listening. Perhaps if the gathering is long, you doze off or speak, even though speaking (during the sermon) is condemned. If you were in amusement or a worldly matter, you would not doze off but would be lively for it. That is only due to the wickedness of your inner self and the weakness of your faith. Where are your fathers, and where are your brothers and loved ones? They have inhabited the bellies of the earth and become food for insects, unable to ward off the punishment they encounter: It is time, so be patient; there is no blaming time... We have no escape from the plan of death. / The cup of death is a necessity... And who is the one who will not drink from its cup? / A wise man does not build up the lowly world... If the builder of life in it is destroyed. / Indeed Ali condemned it in his speech... And divorced it, while the deceived ignoramus proposes to it. / When the jug was brought while people were present... He said to them: O men, marvel! / Indeed, in this jug there are admonitions... For the one who takes heed, who fears the darkness of the grave. / How many a mouth and kohl-lined eye are in it... And smooth cheek that was loved and sought. / And how many of great stature whose bones became... A vessel, and from it, water, O people, is drunk.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: And transferred from one land to another as a gift... So how strange, after decay, to be exiled. O Allah, reform us, reform the corruption of our hearts, reform the corruption of our deeds, reform the corruption of those in charge of our affairs, and reform us with what You reformed Your righteous servants.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Conditions of the Dead. Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: 'The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by two graves and said: They are being punished, and they are not being punished for something major. As for one of them, he did not shield himself from urine. As for the other, he used to walk about with gossip (Namimah). Then he took a fresh palm branch, split it in two, and planted one on each grave. He said: Perhaps it will be lightened for them as long as they do not dry up.' Some of the dead were seen in a dream and asked: 'How was your condition?' He said: 'I prayed one day without ablution, so a wolf was appointed over me to terrify me in my grave, so my condition with him is the worst condition.' Another was seen in sleep and asked: 'What did Allah do with you?' He said: 'Leave me, for I was unable to perform Ghusl (ritual bath) for Janabah one day, so Allah clothed me in a garment of fire in which I turn over night and day.' Jesus, son of Mary, peace be upon him, passed by a cemetery and called a man from them. Allah brought him to life. He said: 'Who are you?' He said: 'I was a porter transporting people. I transported firewood for a person one day and broke a toothpick from it and used it. I have been held accountable for it since I died.' Sufyan Al-Thawri was seen in a dream with two wings flying in Paradise from tree to tree. He was asked: 'By what did you attain this?' He said: 'By Wara' (piety/caution).' Hassan bin Abi Sinan stood over the companions of Al-Hasan and said: 'Which thing is hardest for you?' They said: 'Wara'.' He said: 'Nothing is lighter for me than it.' They said: 'How so?' He said: 'I have not quenched my thirst from your river for forty years.' Hassan bin Abi Sinan did not sleep lying down, nor eat fatty food, nor drink cold water for sixty years. He was seen in a dream after he died and was asked: 'What did Allah do with you?' He said: 'Good, except that I am withheld from Paradise because of a needle I borrowed and did not return.' Abdul Wahid bin Zaid had a boy who served him for years and worshipped his Lord for forty years. In the beginning, he was a measurer (of grain). When he died, he was seen in a dream and asked: 'What did Allah do with you?' He said: 'Good, except that I am withheld from Paradise because forty Qafiz (a measure) of dust from the Qafiz (measuring cup) accumulated against me.' It is narrated that a man came to the graves, prayed two Rak'ahs, then lay down on his side and slept.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: He saw the occupant of the grave in a dream saying: 'This is it. You work but do not know, and we know but do not work. For two Rak'ahs to be in my record is more beloved to me than the world and what is in it.' Some of the righteous said: 'A brother in Allah of mine died, so I saw him in sleep. I said to him: O so-and-so, you lived, praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds. He said to me: Being able to say it—meaning Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds—is more beloved to me than the world and what is in it. Then he said: Did you not see where they were burying me? Indeed, so-and-so came and prayed two Rak'ahs. To be able to pray them is more beloved to me than the world and what is in it.' Abu Sabra mentioned that Munkar and Nakir came to a man in his grave and said: 'We are going to strike you one hundred times.' The dead man said: 'I was such-and-such (righteous),' and he interceded with some of his good deeds until they reduced it by ten. He kept interceding until they reduced it all except one strike. So they struck him one blow, and the grave flared up in fire upon him. He said: 'Why did you strike me?' They said: 'You passed by an oppressed person who sought your help, but you did not help him.' Abdullah bin Umar and a group of his family said: 'We used to pray to Allah Almighty to show us Omar in a dream. I saw him in a dream after twelve years as if he had bathed and was wrapped in a waist wrapper. I said: O Commander of the Faithful, how did you find your Lord and with which of your good deeds did He reward you? He said: O Abdullah, how long has it been since I left you? I said: Twelve years. He said: Since I left you, I was in the Reckoning, and I feared I would perish, except that Allah is Forgiving, Merciful, Generous, and Kind.' This was the condition of Omar, and he possessed nothing of the means of governance in his world except a whip. It is narrated that Abu Shahma, the son of Omar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, committed fornication, so he lashed him one hundred lashes and he died. Forty days later, Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman said: 'I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in a dream, and the youth was with him wearing two green garments. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Convey my greetings to Omar and tell him: Thus do I order you to read the Quran and establish the limits (Hudud). The boy said: O Hudhayfah, convey my greetings to my father and tell him: Allah purified you as you purified me, and peace.' It is narrated from Abu Bakr bin Abi Al-Dunya from his companions that he said to a grave robber after his repentance: 'What is the cause of your repentance and return to Allah?' He said: 'I dug up a person and found him nailed with nails in all his body, and a large nail in his head and another in his feet.' Another said: 'What is the cause of your repentance?' He said: 'I saw the skull of a human into which lead had been poured.'

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: It is narrated that some grave robbers dug up a grave one night. When they uncovered the deceased, behold, a fire was burning the deceased. A spark from it flew towards him, so he fled and repented to Allah Almighty. It was said that Al-Awza'i was seen in a dream and said: 'I have not seen a rank here higher than the rank of the scholars, then the sorrowful ones.' Abu Abdullah Al-Naddad was seen in a dream and asked: 'What did Allah do with you?' He said: 'He made me stand and forgave me every sin I confessed to in the world except one I was shy to confess. So He made me stand in sweat until the flesh of my face fell off.' He was asked: 'What was that?' He said: 'I looked at a beautiful person and was shy to mention it.' It is narrated from Hashim bin Hassan that he said: 'A young son of mine died. I saw him in sleep and his hair was grey. I said: O my son, what is this grey hair? He said: When so-and-so came to us, Hell exhaled a sigh at his arrival; not one of us remained but turned grey.' It was said that when Kurz bin Wabrah died, he was seen in a dream as if the people of the graves came out of their graves wearing new white clothes. It was said: 'What is this?' They said: 'The people of the graves were clothed in new garments for the arrival of Kurz among them.' It is narrated that one of the righteous said: 'I had a son who was martyred. I did not see him in a dream until the night Omar bin Abdul Aziz, may Allah be pleased with him, died. He appeared to me that night. I said: O my son, were you not dead? He said: No, but I was martyred, and I am alive with Allah Almighty, being provided for. I said: What brought you? He said: It was announced among the people of the heavens that no prophet, truthful one (Siddiq), or martyr should remain without attending the prayer for Omar bin Abdul Aziz. So I came to witness the prayer, then I came to you to greet you.' It is narrated that Abdul Wahid bin Abdul Majid Al-Thaqafi said: 'I saw a funeral carried by three men and a woman. I took the place of the woman and we went to the cemetery, prayed over it, and buried it. I said to the woman: Who was this to you? She said: My son. I said: Did you not have neighbors? She said: Yes, but they belittled his affair. I said: And what was this? She said: He was a Mukhannath (effeminate man). He said: So I had mercy on her

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: and took her to my house and gave her Dirhams, wheat, and clothes. I slept that night and saw as if someone came to me looking like the moon on the night of the full moon, wearing white clothes. He began to thank me. I said: Who are you? He said: I am the Mukhannath whom you buried today; my Lord had mercy on me due to the people's contempt for me. Provide for yourself, O brother, with piety. Whoever knows what is before him does not prefer desire. Whoever reflects on the departure of those who were with him becomes certain of the departure himself. How many deceived by their youth and healthy state did death snatch from their midst? How many inclining to gather their wealth left it as inheritance and passed on with their burdens? Did death show mercy to a sick person for the weakness of his limbs? Did it leave a provider for the sake of his children? The events have informed you of their descent... And called out to you, except that your hearing has deafness. / You wail and weep for loved ones if they pass... But your soul does not weep while you are on the trail. O Allah, have mercy on us and do not punish us, grant us victory and do not forsake us, heal us and do not sicken us, honor us and do not humiliate us, prefer us and do not prefer others over us. Indeed, You are over all things competent.

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Signs of the Hour and its Conditions. Allah Almighty said: ([The time of] their account has approached for the people, while they are in heedlessness turning away. No mention comes to them from their Lord [that is] new except that they listen to it while they are at play. With their hearts distracted.) The two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed, among the signs of the Hour is that knowledge will be lifted, ignorance will increase, fornication will increase, wine drinking will increase, men will decrease, and women will increase until there will be one guardian for fifty women.' It is narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'When spoils of war are taken as personal wealth, trust is taken as booty, Zakat is taken as a fine, learning is for other than the religion of Allah, a man obeys his wife and disobeys his mother, brings his friend near and drives his father away, voices are raised in the mosques, the sinner of the tribe becomes their chief, the leader of the people is the vilest of them, a man is honored for fear of his evil, singing girls and musical instruments appear, wines are drunk, and the last of this nation curses the first of it; then watch for a red wind, an earthquake, a landslide, transformation, and signs following one another like the beads of a cut necklace following one another.' From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned a trial that will afflict this nation until a man cannot find a refuge to seek shelter from oppression. Then Allah will send a man from my lineage and my family who will fill the earth with equity and justice as it was filled with tyranny and oppression. The inhabitants of the heaven and the inhabitants of the earth will be pleased with him. The sky will not leave any of its rain but pour it abundantly, and the earth will not leave any of its vegetation but bring it forth, until the living will wish for the dead. He will live in that for seven years, or eight years, or nine years. In Sahih Muslim, from Hudhayfah bin Asid Al-Ghifari, he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, looked out upon us while we were discussing. He said: 'What are you discussing?' They said: We are mentioning the Hour. He said: 'Indeed, it will not be established until'

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: you see ten signs before it.' He mentioned the Smoke, the Dajjal (Antichrist), the Beast, the rising of the sun from its west, the descent of Jesus son of Mary, Gog and Magog, and three landslides: a landslide in the East, a landslide in the West, and a landslide in the Arabian Peninsula. And the last of that is a fire emerging from Yemen driving the people to their gathering place.' In Sahih Muslim, he said: 'Three things, if they emerge, no soul will benefit from its faith if it had not believed before: The rising of the sun from its west, the Dajjal, and the Beast of the Earth.' There is difference of opinion regarding the first of the signs. It was said the first is the rising of the sun from its west and the emergence of the Beast. It came in the narration of Ibn Abi Shaybah from Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: 'Whichever of the two comes before its companion, the other is right on its trail.' The Beast of the Earth is sixty cubits tall, having legs and fur. It is said it has a mixed creation resembling several animals. Mount Safa will crack open and it will emerge from it on the night of Jam' (gathering at Muzdalifah) while people are descending to Mina. It is said it will emerge from the land of Ta'if. With it are the Staff of Moses and the Ring of Solomon, peace be upon them. No seeker can catch it, and no fleer can escape it. It strikes the believer with the Staff, marking his face as 'Believer', and stamps the disbeliever with the Ring, marking his face as 'Disbeliever'. In Sahih Muslim, from Al-Nawas bin Sam'an, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned the Dajjal and said: 'If he emerges while I am among you, I will argue with him on your behalf. And if he emerges and I am not among you, then every man must argue for himself, and Allah is my Successor over every Muslim. He is a young man with curly hair, his eye is floating (blind/defective). I liken him to Abdul Uzza bin Qatan. Whoever among you encounters him, let him read the opening verses of Surah Al-Kahf over him, for they are your protection from his trial. He will emerge on a road between the Levant (Sham) and Iraq. He will spread corruption to the right and corruption to the left. O servants of Allah, stand firm.' We said: O Messenger of Allah, how long will he stay on earth? He said: 'Forty days: a day like a year, a day like a month, a day like a week, and the rest of his days like your days.' We said: For that day which is like a year, will the prayer of one day suffice us? He said: 'No, estimate for it its measure.' We said: O Messenger of Allah, and what is'

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: his speed in the earth? He said: 'Like the rain driven by the wind. He will come to a people and invite them, and they will believe in him. He will command the sky and it will rain, and the earth and it will grow vegetation. Their livestock will return to them in the evening with the highest humps, the fullest udders, and the widest flanks. Then he will come to a people and invite them, and they will reject his word. He will turn away from them, and they will become drought-stricken, having nothing of their wealth in their hands. He will pass by a ruin and say to it: Bring out your treasures. And its treasures will follow him like drones of bees. Then he will call a man brimming with youth, strike him with the sword, and cut him into two pieces like a shot target. Then he will call him, and he will come forward, his face beaming and laughing. While he is like that, Allah will send the Messiah, son of Mary. He will descend at the white minaret east of Damascus between two yellow garments, placing his hands on the wings of two angels. If he lowers his head, it drips, and if he raises it, drops like pearls descend from it. No disbeliever will find the scent of his breath except that he will die, and his breath reaches as far as his eye can see. He will seek him (Dajjal) until he catches him at the gate of Lod and kills him. Then a people whom Allah has protected from him will come to Jesus, and he will wipe their faces and tell them of their ranks in Paradise. While he is like that, Allah will reveal to Jesus: I have brought out servants of Mine against whom no one has the power to fight, so take My servants safely to Al-Tur (the Mount). Allah will send Gog and Magog, and they will swarm down from every mound. The first of them will pass by the Lake of Tiberias and drink what is in it, and the last of them will pass and say: There was once water here. Then they will march until they reach the Mountain of Khamr, which is the mountain of Bayt al-Maqdis (Jerusalem). They will say: We have killed those on earth, come let us kill those in the sky. So they will throw their arrows towards the sky, and Allah will return their arrows to them dyed with blood. The Prophet of Allah and his companions will be besieged until the head of a bull for one of them is better than a hundred dinars for one of you today. The Prophet of Allah Jesus and his companions will beseech Allah, so Allah will send upon them (Gog and Magog) worms (Naghaf) in their necks, and they will become corpses like the death of a single soul. Then the Prophet of Allah and his companions will descend to the earth, but they will not find a place of a hand span on earth except that their fat and stench has filled it.' It is narrated 'zahmahum' with a Damma on the Zay and Fatha on the Ha, meaning a stench. 'And their stink. So the Prophet of Allah Jesus and his companions will beseech Allah, and Allah will send birds like the necks of Bactrian camels. They will carry them and throw them where Allah wills.' It is narrated 'tatrahuhum' (throw them) into the Nahil (sea/valley). 'And the Muslims will use their bows, arrows, and quivers as firewood for seven years. Then Allah will send a rain from which no

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: mud-brick house or tent will shelter. It will wash the earth until it leaves it like a mirror. Then it will be said to the earth: Grow your fruits and return your blessings. On that day, a group will eat from a pomegranate and seek shade under its skin. Milk will be blessed such that a milch-camel will suffice a large group of people, a milch-cow will suffice a tribe of people, and a milch-sheep will suffice a clan of people. While they are like that, Allah will send a pleasant wind that will seize them under their armpits and take the soul of every believer and every Muslim. The worst of people will remain, copulating in public like donkeys, and upon them the Hour will be established.' Some recited: Represent to your heart, O deceived one... The Day of Resurrection and the sky shaking. / The sun of the day has been wound up and multiplied... In heat upon the heads of servants, boiling. / And when the mountains are uprooted from their foundations... And you see them moving like clouds. / And when the pregnant camels are neglected by their owners... The homes are empty, no deceived one is in them. / And when the stars fall and scatter... And change after light to darkness. / And when the wild beasts are gathered after Resurrection... And say to the angels: Where do we go? / It is said: Go, witness scandals... And wonders that have been brought and matters. / And when the fetus clings to its mother... Fearful of the Account, and his heart is terrified. / This is without sin, he fears its horror... How then the one remaining in sins for ages?

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: The Blowing of the Horn. Allah Almighty said: (And the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on. And the earth will shine with the light of its Lord, and the record [of deeds] will be placed, and the prophets and the witnesses will be brought, and it will be judged between them in truth, and they will not be wronged. And every soul will be fully compensated [for] what it did; and He is most knowing of what they do. And those who disbelieved will be driven to Hell in groups until, when they reach it, its gates are opened and its keepers will say, 'Did there not come to you messengers from yourselves, reciting to you the verses of your Lord and warning you of the meeting of this Day of yours?' They will say, 'Yes, but the word of punishment has come into effect upon the disbelievers.' It will be said, 'Enter the gates of Hell to abide eternally therein, and wretched is the residence of the arrogant.' And those who feared their Lord will be driven to Paradise in groups until, when they reach it while its gates have been opened and its keepers say, 'Peace be upon you; you have become pure; so enter it to abide eternally therein,' [they will enter]. And they will say, 'Praise to Allah, who has fulfilled for us His promise and made us inherit the earth [so] we may settle in Paradise wherever we will. And excellent is the reward of [righteous] workers.' And you will see the angels surrounding the Throne, exalting [Allah] with praise of their Lord. And it will be judged between them in truth, and it will be said, '[All] praise to Allah, Lord of the worlds.') In the book of Al-Nasa'i from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'How can I be comfortable while the owner of the Horn has put the Horn in his mouth, inclined his ear, and lowered his forehead waiting for when he will be ordered to blow, so he will blow.' They said: O Messenger of Allah, what should we say? He said: 'Say: Allah is Sufficient for us and He is the Best Disposer of affairs; upon Allah we rely.' In Sahih Muslim, from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: say: 'The people will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection barefoot, naked, and uncircumcised.' I said: O Messenger of Allah, women and men together, looking at one another? He said: 'O Aisha, the matter is more severe than for them to look at one another.' In the book of Tirmidhi from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The people will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection in three categories: a category walking, a category riding, and a category on their faces.' It was said: O Messenger of Allah, how will they walk on their faces? He said: 'Indeed, the One who made them walk on their feet in the world is Able to make them walk on their faces. Lo, they will shield themselves with their faces from every obstacle and thorn.' In Sahih Al-Bukhari from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: 'The people will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection in three categories: those hoping and fearing; and two on a camel, three on a camel, four on a camel, and ten on a camel; and the rest of them will be gathered by the Fire, taking a midday nap with them wherever they nap, staying the night with them wherever they stay the night, reaching the morning with them wherever they reach the morning, and reaching the evening with them wherever they reach the evening.' And in it, he, peace be upon him, said: 'Allah will seize the earth on the Day of Resurrection and fold the sky with His Right Hand, then He will say: I am the King, where are the kings of the earth?' And in it, he said: 'The people will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection on a reddish-white land like a loaf of pure bread.' Sahl or someone else said: 'There is no landmark for anyone in it.' And it is authentic that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The dead is resurrected in the clothes in which he died.' It was said: The meaning of clothes is deeds, but Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri interpreted it literally. In Sahih Muslim from Al-Miqdad bin Al-Aswad, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: 'The sun will draw near to the creation on the Day of Resurrection until it is like the measure of a mile.' Sulaym bin Amir said: By Allah, I do not know what he means by the mile: the distance on earth or the stick (mil) used to apply kohl to the eye. He said: 'So the people will be in sweat according to their deeds. Among them are those whom it reaches to their ankles, among them are those whom it reaches to their knees, among them are those whom it reaches to their waists, and among them are those whom the sweat bridles completely.' The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, gestured with his hand to his mouth. In the Musnad of Abu Bakr Al-Bazzar from Jabir bin Abdullah, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Indeed

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: sweat will adhere to a person in the Standing Place until he says: O Lord, sending me to the Fire is easier for me than what I am experiencing—while he knows what severe punishment is in it. Some of the predecessors said: If the sun rose on the earth as it will be on the Day of Resurrection, it would burn the earth, melt the rock, and dry up the rivers. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Seven are those whom Allah Almighty will shade in His shade on the Day when there is no shade but His shade: A just Imam; a youth who grew up in the worship of Allah; a man whose heart is attached to the mosque when he leaves it until he returns to it; two men who loved each other in Allah, met upon that and separated upon that; a man who remembered Allah in solitude and his eyes overflowed; a man whom a woman of beauty and status invited (to sin) and he said: I fear Allah; and a man who gave charity and hid it so that his left hand did not know what his right hand spent.' Al-Hasan Al-Basri, may Allah have mercy on him, said: 'What is your opinion of a day in which they stood on their feet for the duration of fifty thousand years, not eating a meal in it, nor drinking a drink, until their necks were severed from thirst and their insides burned from hunger? Then they were taken to the Fire and given drink from a boiling spring—meaning extremely hot—over which Hell has been stoked since it was created.'

book_title: Preparation for Death and the Questioning of the Grave
text: Intercession of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Allah Almighty said: (Who is it that can intercede with Him except by His permission?) In Sahih Al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him: Meat was brought to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and the foreleg was offered to him, which he used to like. He took a bite from it and then said: 'I am the master of the people on the Day of Resurrection. Do you know why that is? Allah will gather the first and the last on a single plain so that a caller can make them hear and the sight can penetrate them. The sun will draw near, and the people will reach a level of distress and grief that they cannot bear or endure. The people will say: Do you not see what has reached you? Do you not look for someone to intercede for you with your Lord? Some people will say to others: Your father Adam. So they will go to Adam and say: You are the father of mankind; Allah created you with His Hand, breathed into you from His Spirit, and commanded the angels to prostrate to you. Intercede for us with your Lord. Do you not see what we are in? Do you not see what has reached us? Adam will say: Indeed, my Lord has become angry today with an anger the likes of which He has never been angry before and will never be angry after. Indeed, He forbade me from the tree and I disobeyed Him. Myself, myself, myself. Go to someone else; go to Noah. They will go to Noah and say: You are the first of the messengers to the earth, and Allah named you a grateful servant. Do you not see what we are in? Do you not see what has reached us? Will you not intercede for us with your Lord? He will say: Indeed, my Lord has become angry today with an anger the likes of which He has never been angry before and will never be angry after. Indeed, I had a supplication which I made against my people. Myself, myself, myself. Go to someone else; go to Abraham. They will go to Abraham and say: O Abraham, you are the Prophet of Allah and His Friend (Khalil) from the people of the earth. Intercede for us with your Lord. Do you not see what we are in? He will say to them: Indeed, my Lord has become angry today with an anger the likes of which He has never been angry before and will never be angry after. Indeed, I told three lies. Myself, myself, myself. Go to someone else; go to Moses. They will go to Moses and say: O Moses, you are the Messenger of Allah; Allah favored you with His message and His speech over the people.
